instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PUBS_G3H: What is PUBS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PUBS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message:
Hi all,

I have an [URL="tel:<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>"]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL] that is completely dead.

This is the history so far:

- No green light and 9 volts on <SIGNAL>PUBS_G3H</SIGNAL>

- Replaced <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> because it looked like it had a hole in it

- Green light restored

- Powered up normally.

I then plugged it back into the power supply and <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> started burning up then the whole thing died, so i replaced it and now i get nothing.

No green light, no voltage anywhere, on the power supply it just defaults to 2v and 1.14 amps.

I assume the PCH and SMC are okay as it did power on but now i have no idea.

I tried to inject voltage on the DC in fuse but again defaults to 2v and 1.14 amps.

PP3V42 Resistance to ground = 041.8 ohms
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Resistance to ground = 000.5 ohms --> i assume this is the problem but how can i check whats shorted if I can’t inject voltage?

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: ISL is dead again. Replace ISL <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35. Also check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and resistance between pins 17/18 27/28 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Thanks Duke - will get to it tomorrow??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message:
Okay so replaced all of those and i have 16v coming in and green light - but drawing 0 amps and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 0.1v

Any idea what to do next? it seems ISL is not creating the 12v but it's been replaced twice now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Current sensing seems fine too - Pins 27/28 are 20.3 ohms and 17/18 are 3 ohms (might be a bit high?)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Resistance to GND on PPBUS? ISL soldered correctly? <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> checked?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Resistance to ground on PPBUS is 400k approx System side and 600k the other. ISL looks good and <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> measures and looks okay too. Confused.com?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Check if 16V is present on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>. If it is present you probably have bad soldering somewhere or killed the ISL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Okay thanks Duke - I’ll leave it at that and close this??
